Posts.Content: Ronstar - I can really empathise with your shoulder problems.  I've had ongoing shoulder problems pre cancer - I broke my right shoulder 5 years ago, had surgery on it 18 months later, then had a nerve block 18 months after that - all this time having regular Physio.  The nerve block eventually worked giving me a good range of movement, then I developed problems in my left shoulder - probably due to overuse while my right side was out of action.  I'd been having Physio on my left shoulder since earlier in 2016, had a steroid injection to reduce inflammation, just started intensive Physio then was diagnosed with left side breast cancer.  I've really really tried to keep up with the post surgery exercises and saw a Physio at the hospital who treats breast cancer patients - it hasn't helped that I fell on Boxing Day and landed on my left arm!   I've not started radiotherapy yet, had my planning appt yesterday and found both shoulders really hurt when in the armrests.  The radiologist suggested I take painkillers an hour before my sessions.  I don't know whether you're on other medication, but I take amitriptyline which does seem to help a bit with the pain. Must admit that I am a bit worried about the joint pain as a side effect of the anastrozole, although I've not had issues yet, only mega hot flushes and night sweats, nausea, indigestion and headaches!  Jane
Posts.Title: Being fit and well is such a long way off

Posts.Content: My breast is still swollen and sore to the touch nearly 4 weeks post surgery.  The wound has healed well and when I saw the surgeon 10 days ago, she said it was fluid causing the swelling and my body would eventually reabsorb it. Jane
Posts.Title: Breast cancer and operation
petition the government to continue Kadcyla for breast cancer patients...

Posts.Content: Jojo4 So no sleep last night, panicked all day then strangely calmer this evening.  Now just got in bed and the terror has arrived again.  I've convinced myself that because I have very very large breasts (38jj) I didn't find my lump until it was at least 6cm and that means that it will be the very worst news.  US can't see anything in LN but I'm now panicking over that and what may be revealed in surgery.  I really want to get off this roller coaster.  Nights are always the worst - I already take a drug called amitriptyline at night for nerve pain, but it usually helps me sleep, however I have been at my highest dose for the last month and managing an hour or two if I'm lucky. Following the, in my mind, devastating news I had on Monday, the day I had my preoperative assessment and date of 25th November for surgery, when I received a call to say they had re-looked at my MRI scan and I needed MRI guided biopsy on a suspicious area in my other breast, I spoke over the phone to my GP who has added another medication to take at night, and I'm now having 4-5 hours which is better.  I'm still struggling with constant anxiety during the day and struggling to eat, even chocolate!, which isn't good especially as people keep giving it to me.   Work was my saving grace for the first few weeks, I work in a busy school environment, and it was a welcome.  However, since Monday I have had to make the decision to take time off. My current mental state means I am really struggling to function normally. Even cooking tea last night felt like a mountain to climb.  I'm wondering whether the GP will prescribe something to take during the day just to stop the horrible adrenaline feeling in my tummy. Love this forum as can share mutual experiences and realise I'm not alone..
Posts.Title: 2nd night of waiting: even more terrified

Posts.Content: I had my op on 2nd December. Left breast WLE, wound runs across the top of my breast to underneath my arm.  Surgeon did sentinel node biopsy through same cut.  Wound lumpy with a red spot the size of a pea at the far end - been told not to worry as apparently it's where the end of the disolvable stitches are.  Breast is still very numb and very blue from the dye!  Been doing the exercises religiously as had a frozen shoulder injected with steroid back in September and shoulder mobility not too good.  Bit worried about the positioning for radiotherapy really.  Jane
Posts.Title: Tell me about your scars

Posts.Content: Hello warmauburn My urine was bright blue from the first time I emptied my bladder post surgery, the colour gradually faded over the next 5 days; apparently my skin was a strange bluey-grey colour and the nurses kept taking my blood pressure and wouldn't take the oxygen away until one noticed I was being over oxygenated!  The surgeon had warned me and my oh I might look a strange colour, but the nursing staff obviously didn't know this!! My poo was also bright green when I eventually opened my bowels post surgery!  My breast still has a bright blue patch on it 5 weeks post surgery.  It's now accompanied by the little black tattoos ready for my radiotherapy to start - just looking forward to the red skin as well from the radiotherapy! Jane
Posts.Title: Tell me about your scars

Posts.Content: The guide wire was used to guide the surgeon to the tumour for the wide local excision.  Sorry to hear you have another health issue.  A friend had some fine needle biopsies but hers turned out to be non malignant calcifications. Jane x
Posts.Title: Titanium marker

Posts.Content: My titanium marker didn't get lost but it had moved.. When I had the guide wire inserted by ultrasound before the surgery, the marker was about an inch away from the tumour. I've worried a bit since that they didn't actually biopsy the tumour, so the resulting grade/ er status might not be completely accurate, as this wasn't rechecked on the pathology of the tumour - mind you I am a bit of a worried at the moment! jane
Posts.Title: Titanium marker

Posts.Content: Thank you to all who've answered my worries. When I have my reasonable head on, I can understand that the oncologist wouldn't do anything that would jeopardise his job, and, both my husband and I accepted his reasoning at the time.  I am wondering whether the anastrozole is affecting my mood, I only started it a week ago but I'm so up and down and acting quite unreasonably today.  lets hope tomorrow's a better day!  Jane
Posts.Title: Anybody heard or used the Oncotype Dx test for deciding treatment...

Posts.Content: I had my treatment privately, and the insurance were happy to pay for the oncotype testing, but my oncologist felt it wasn't necessary.  But just reading anncg's result I feel worried - I had a 9mm invasive ductal cancer, her- and er+. I had a WLE and sentinel node biopsy. Sentinel node was clear but there were isolated tumour cells, but still classed as clear.  I'm having radiotherapy and anastrozole for 5 years.  I'm finding it really difficult at the moment - I know you have to trust your medical team but when I read that others with a similar diagnosis have needed further treatment it just feeds my anxiety. Jane
Posts.Title: Anybody heard or used the Oncotype Dx test for deciding treatment...

Posts.Content: My surgeon thinks it will be radiotherapy and anastrozole for 5 years. I asked about the oncotype dx testing but apparently it doesn't need doing - I will chat to the oncologist on Thursday. I'm just really worried about these individual tumour cells - need to find out why they're not a cause for concern.  It's just such an anxious time isn't it - so much waiting and the lack of control of your own destiny.  At least our appointments are before Christmas! Jane
Posts.Title: I have my results

Posts.Content: What a relief for you - we must be at the same stage - I had my results last Friday - clear margins and negative nodes but some individual tumour cells in the node capsule. Seeing the oncologist to discuss this on Thursday.   Bet you'll have more sleep tonight! Jane
Posts.Title: I have my results

Posts.Content: Thank you all for your replies - I'm still struggling to understand why isolated tumour cells within the capsule of the lymph node class as node negative.  I have visions of these cells invading elsewhere - my only wish was that there was no tumour invasion in my lymph nodes, I felt I could cope better with needing a wider margin removed from the tumour site.  I know I should be counting my blessings as so many are worse off but I can't get it out of my mind that if there are itc's in one lymph node might there be some in the other nodes, and as far as I know, I'm not receiving further treatment on the nodes, just radiotherapy on my breast.  Jane
Posts.Title: Worried about pathology report

Posts.Content: Unfortunately my BCN is on leave until after Christmas. My oh has actually emailed my surgeon to see whether she can offer any more information - I don't just need to be told it's nothing to worry about, I need to understand why it's nothing to worry about.  If you look at my profile you can see what an emotional roller coaster I've been on, for what to all intents and purposes is a low grade cancer and initially I was told it was easily sorted. I think the emotional impact has really hit me this weekend.  Jane
Posts.Title: Worried about pathology report

Posts.Content: I've just received my pathology report following a WLE and sentinel node biopsy.  My surgeon is pleased as the tumour was removed with clear margins and was a grade 1 invasive ductal carcinoma, and the report states the lymph node was negative - however there is a statement which reads "there are isolated tumour cells in the capsule of the node and an intravenous capsular naevus". My surgeon tried to reassure me that this was nothing to worry about - but I've just got home and am so worried and anxious again.  Surely if there are malignant cells on the biopsy they could also be elsewhere.  I have searched for information on this site but couldn't find anyone with a similar pathology. Your thoughts would be very much appreciated. Jane
Posts.Title: Worried about pathology report

Posts.Content: I've just read this thread with interest, my children are 24 and 27, with the 27 year old being a doctor. They've both dealt with it differently.  My older child has dealt with it on a practical level, using his medical background, but has also been contacting more than usual, just to check in.  My younger child seems to be keeping her feelings to herself, although she is popping home from London for the weekend to, in her words, use up a train ticket. My problem is talking about it to my elderly parents, both in their mid 80s and my mum with quite severe memory issues.  I feel my dad has enough on his plate dealing with mum without me causing further worries.  However, I felt I needed to say something as, obviously if I need chemotherpy I will change visually.  At the moment I have said that a small lump was identified during a routine mammogram, which is true, and that they want to remove it to be on the safe side.  My dad did say, is it benign or malignant, and I just said it is might be malignant. Due to lots of issues regarding scans and biopsies my surgery has been postponed, so I will just give them enough information to be honest but not to go into too much detail.
Posts.Title: Children

Posts.Content: I typed a long reply and it's disappeared!! I'm 8 weeks post WLE and senrinel node biopsy.  I have developed  a thickening along the top of my breast running away from the scar over the last two weeks, but it has gradually got more swollen and the skin is a bit discoloured, sort of bluish.  Saw my BCN this week before I started my radiotherapy and she thinks it's a haematoma from the surgery.  I did have a big haematoma post surgery which cleared, but she said it's not unheard for another one to appear.  The radiotherapy team are just monitoring it at the moment, and I have an appt next week with the oncologist before my 5 booster rads so he will check it then. Jane
Posts.Title: Lump developed during radiotherapy ?

Posts.Content: I've been on anastrozole for 3 weeks and my BCN has said that different brands cause different side effects, but that I need to stick with 1 for 2-3 months to see if the side effects improve.  Just picked up my new prescription and have opened the bag at Home and it's a different brand. Do I take it, or should I go back to the pharmacy to see if the can get the Teva brand they dispensed last month. Just wondered whether anyone has any experience.
Posts.Title: Different manufacturer of anastrozole

Posts.Content: Thank you for taking the time to reply. The new tablets are manufactured by Wockhardt uk.  Think I will go down to the pharmacist tomorrow and discuss it with him. Jane
Posts.Title: Different manufacturer of anastrozole
